title: Wembley developer Quintain scores £700m bid from privaty equity firm Lone Star
text:

Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 11:02 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 28 mins Wembley developer Quintain scores £700m bid from privaty equity firm Lone Star By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 13 minutes ago +24.2936 
Quintain's share price rocketed by almost 25pc following the news 
Quintain, the developer behind the redevelopment of Wembley, has received a £700m acquisition offer from private equity house Lone Star. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in Quintain Estates and Development (LSE: QED.L - news ) , which owns 85 acres of land surrounding London’s Wembley Arena and Stadium , jumped 24.5pc to 131.50p on Wednesday morning after its board unanimously recommended the takeover offer from the US-based firm. 
The company said Quintain shareholders would receive 131p in cash for each share, valuing it at £700m. 
The private equity group said it was attracted to the potential for the company’s land around Wembley Stadium. 
"The proposed acquisition represents a unique opportunity for Lone Star to gain further exposure to residential and commercial assets in London," said Lone Star's Angus Dodd. 
"Wembley Park is one of the largest and most exciting urban renewal projects in Europe and complements our experience in this segment of the market," he added. 
"We intend to contribute significant additional financial resources to help Quintain in its next phase of growth: to accelerate delivery at Wembley Park, building more homes more quickly and continuing the creation of a cohesive and exciting new community." 
Quintain, which is listed on London's Stock Exchange, was launched in 1992. 
Between 2000 and 2002, it bought up land around the Wembley Arena, sprucing up the venue and installing a discount outlet shopping centre nearby to attract more footfall to the area. 
It has spent £0.5bn on the development in the last 15 years. 
Wembley during its redevelopment by Quintain in 2005 
The company has planning permission to build 5,000 homes from Brent Council, and is hoping to turn the area into a start-up hub through a mixture of cheap rents and super-fast broadband. 
“There was one single curry house here when we bought the land, that’s all it had to offer,” said Quintain's chief operating officer James Saunders. “The area needed places to work and places to live.” 
The London Designer Outlet shopping centre now attracts 150,000 visitors a week, more than the stadium and arena combined. It has also attracted a number of chain restaurants and bars to the area, from Wagamama to Nando's. 
In April, Quintain formed a joint venture with Swiss private equity house Keystone to construct 362 homes. It has redeveloped York House, a former office, which is now home to 40 businesses. 
There is also a new 1,300-seat theatre on the way, which will open in September 2016 with the first live show of The Hunger Games . A five-acre park could be finished as early as next year, complete with lakes. 
Quintain was forced to focus on office space instead of residential property when the recession hit , sending the market into chronic decline. “The residential market evaporated in 2009,” said Mr Saunders. ”We didn’t know when it would come back.” 
To reduce the pressure on cash flow, Quintain offloaded its interests in the Greenwich Peninsula for £230m, which delivered it a £31m profit. Revenue was £13.1m in the six months to 30 September, from £19.9m a year ago. 
Last week Quintain reported half year pre-tax profits of £8m, from a loss of £25.2m in 2014. 
Mr Saunders said that Quintain would remain involved in the redevelopment for the next 20 years.
